metadata.title: Compound Interest & The Rule of 72
metadata.subtitle: Discover the 'eighth wonder of the world' and learn how to calculate when your money will double using a simple formula

content.title: Compound Interest & The Rule of 72
content.subtitle: Discover the 'eighth wonder of the world' and learn how to calculate when your money will double using a simple formula in {{STATE_NAME}}

content.label: Essential Question
content.question:
How can $1,000 turn into $4,322
without adding another dollar?

The secret is compound interest ‚Äî earning interest on your interest. Understanding this powerful concept is the key to building wealth over time.

objectives.description: Between simple interest and compound interest and explain why the difference matters
The Rule of 72 to estimate how long it takes for money to double at different interest rates
Future value of investments using compound interest to see the power of time
Opportunity costs of spending vs. investing and understand the true cost of purchases

terms.definition: The initial amount of money you deposit or invest ‚Äî your starting point
terms.example: You deposit $1,000 into a savings account. That $1,000 is your principal.

terms.definition: Interest calculated only on the original principal amount, never changing
terms.example: $1,000 at 5% simple interest = $50/year, every year (always calculated on $1,000)

terms.definition: Interest earned on both the principal AND previously earned interest ‚Äî 'interest on interest'
A formula to estimate how many years it takes for money to double: 72 √∑ interest rate (%)
terms.example: At 6% interest: 72 √∑ 6 = 12 years to double your money

leftPanel.title: The $1,822 Difference
paragraphs: With simple interest, you earn the same amount each year on your original principal. With compound interest, you earn on your growing balance ‚Äî and the difference is dramatic over time.
bulletPoints: Compound interest grows exponentially, not linearly

stats.label: More growth with compounding vs. simple

rightColumn.title: Compound Interest (curves upward)
items: Interest earned on interest each year

layoutData.title: A Shortcut to Estimate Doubling Time
paragraphs: The Formula: Years to Double = 72 √∑ Interest Rate (%)

leftPanel.title: Opportunity Cost Revealed
paragraphs: Every dollar has future potential through compounding. Small choices today create massive differences over decades.
bulletPoints: Small choices today = massive differences later

stats.label: What that $100 could become in 40 years at 7%

content.headerTitle: Why This Matters for Your Future

layoutData.title: Time Is Your Superpower
bulletPoints: Start at 20: Invest $200/month until 65 at 8% = $958,000 (Total invested: $108,000)
Start at 30: Invest $200/month until 65 at 8% = $414,000 (Total invested: $84,000)
10-year delay costs $544,000 ‚Äî despite investing more money total!

keyPoint.text: üí° The best time to start was yesterday. The second best time is today.

leftPanel.title: Modern Tools for Growth
paragraphs: Today's technology makes it easier than ever to put compound interest to work for you.
bulletPoints: High-Yield Savings ‚Äî Online banks offer 4-5% APY
Retirement Accounts ‚Äî Tax advantages boost compounding
Dividend Reinvestment ‚Äî Compounds your stock gains

stats.label: Value of $10K invested in S&P 500 in 1970
Best compounding frequency to maximize growth

scenario.name: Amanda ‚Äî Saving for a Laptop
paragraphs: Amanda wants to save $1,200 for a new laptop. She has $600 now and puts it in a savings account earning 3% interest compounded annually. Using the Rule of 72: 72 √∑ 3 = 24 years to double her money.
At 3%, it takes 24 years to double ‚Äî too long! Amanda's solutions: find a higher interest rate, add monthly contributions, or both.

scenario.name: Micah ‚Äî Teaching His Brother
paragraphs: Micah explains the power of multiple doublings: if his brother invests just $100 with an 8% annual return (Rule of 72: doubles every 9 years).
$100 becomes $800 in just 27 years ‚Äî three doublings with no additional contributions needed.

content.question:
If you had $500 to either spend today or invest for 40 years, what would you choose and why?

At 8%, that $500 becomes about $10,860 in 40 years. What would you have to buy today to make spending worthwhile? How do you balance enjoying money now vs. building future wealth?

Why might someone choose an investment with a lower interest rate even though it takes longer to double?

Consider the relationship between risk and reward. What trade-offs exist between fast growth and safety? When might stability be more important than maximum growth potential?

questions.question: What is the main difference between simple interest and compound interest?
Using the Rule of 72, how long would it take to double your money at 4% interest?
Why is starting to invest early more powerful than investing more money later?
If you spend $50 today instead of investing it, what is the true opportunity cost over 40 years at 7%?

takeaways.title: Compound Beats Simple
takeaways.description: Compound interest earns returns on your returns, growing your money exponentially faster than simple interest

takeaways.title: Use the Rule of 72
takeaways.description: Divide 72 by your interest rate to quickly estimate doubling time. At 6%, money doubles every 12 years

takeaways.title: Time Is Everything
takeaways.description: Starting early matters more than starting big. A 10-year head start can mean twice the final amount

takeaways.title: Think in Future Value
takeaways.description: Every dollar spent today could be worth 10-15√ó more in 40 years. Consider the true opportunity cost

main.title: Rule of 72 Calculator
main.description: Practice applying the Rule of 72 and compound interest calculations to understand the real impact of interest rates and time on your savings. Materials: Calculator, spreadsheet template.

steps: Review the variables ‚Äî Set initial investment ($500), monthly contribution ($50), rate (5%)
Calculate growth ‚Äî Determine total value after 10 years with compound interest
Complete Rule of 72 table ‚Äî Calculate doubling time for rates 2%, 4%, 6%, 8%, 10%, 12%
Compare results ‚Äî Analyze how rate changes affect your wealth-building timeline
Reflect ‚Äî Apply learnings to a personal financial goal

content.tagline: Let Your Money Work for You
